title: [BUG] BGSAVE performance order of magnitude slower in Redis 6.2
body:
**Describe the bug**

RDB save performance experienced a massive degradation for our dataset in 6.2. This week I've been upgrading some 4.0.10 servers to new ones. Initially I used the latest stable (6.2.1) until noticing that RDB creation times were extremely slow. I then installed 6.0.12 and everything was normal again.

The dataset in this case is a ~150 GB (in memory) dataset mostly consisting of sorted sets. Sizes vary but figure 100k-10M members per set. There's also some regular key/value data, I'm not sure on the memory distribution among keys but hopefully that gives a general idea. The RDB files come out around 21 GB.

The new instances (EC2) are the Graviton2 r6gd class, so I was curious if this problem was exclusive to ARM CPUs, but further testing suggests that's not the case. Here's the cases I tried:

original master/replica timing:
z1d (master) on 4.0.10: `rdb_last_bgsave_time_sec:727`
x1e (replica) on 4.0.10: `rdb_last_bgsave_time_sec:1131`

ARM and x86-64 on latest stable:
r6gd (replica) on 6.2.1: `rdb_last_bgsave_time_sec:4952`
z1d (replica) on 6.2.1: `rdb_last_bgsave_time_sec:6757`

dropping back to 6.0.12:
r6gd (replica) on 6.0.12: `rdb_last_bgsave_time_sec:301`

All servers were set up to dump to ephemeral SSD, the r6gd 6.2.1 test and 6.0.12 test were performed on the same instance back to back and the only difference was that I built/installed (from source) the different version of redis and restarted the service.

**To reproduce**

I reckon just set up a big DB in 6.0.12 and 6.2.1 and execute a bgsave, see how long it takes. May be more sensitive to a dataset with many big-ish sorted sets.

**Expected behavior**

Suppose it depends on the underlying hardware but my testing indicates there's roughly an order of magnitude of difference in the amount of time bgsave takes between version 6.0.12 (and earlier) and 6.2.1 on the same hardware.

comments_data.body:
@karock can you please try to disable this change: https://github.com/redis/redis/blob/367ba4125fa08440f1e33799ccf2fedfe88129aa/src/rdb.c#L1277
i.e. you can set it to happen only once:
```c
if ((key_count++) == 0) {
```

i tried to measure rdb saving with and without it, and didn't see any difference, but that's the only change i can think of in that area.
another random thought is that maybe the metric got broken somehow, can you please try to match these to the timestaps in the log messages?

Metric is correct. I didn't confirm via timestamp but it definitely took forever to finish. It also affected the rdb creation time when syncing a new replica which is why I noticed. Will try the code change out probably next week.

I set up a new server as a replica to get our dataset and then `replicaof no one` to remove all load, then started a bgsave:

6.2.1:
```
1689:M 10 Mar 2021 09:09:14.816 * Background saving started by pid 19290
19290:C 10 Mar 2021 10:30:14.445 * DB saved on disk
19290:C 10 Mar 2021 10:30:15.713 * RDB: 3 MB of memory used by copy-on-write
1689:M 10 Mar 2021 10:30:17.563 * Background saving terminated with success
```

then edited rdb.c to make the `if ((key_count++) == 0) {` change
make clean, make, make install
started the redis service back up (it pulled in the previous rdb automatically, no replication involved here)

```
686:M 10 Mar 2021 14:00:12.066 * Background saving started by pid 1465
1465:C 10 Mar 2021 14:05:07.964 * DB saved on disk
1465:C 10 Mar 2021 14:05:09.229 * RDB: 1 MB of memory used by copy-on-write
686:M 10 Mar 2021 14:05:11.093 * Background saving terminated with success
```

`rdb_last_bgsave_time_sec:299`

looks like that's the issue.

@karock I tried to reproduce this myself but I don't experience this behavior.

It's most likely some operation that is unexpectedly expensive on your system (e.g. reading of `/proc/self/smaps`, blocking writing to the parent pipe, etc.). Can you please provide some more info to help reproduce or troubleshoot this:

* What OS/version you're using, and whether or not you're running in a container
* Output of `INFO`
* Some runtime stats about the bgsave child process while it's running (e.g. utime, stime, etc.)

OS is Amazon Linux 2, no containerization. redis is the only service running on this r6gd.8xlarge instance.

Wow.. 1 second just to generate the file (not including parsing)... 
I suggest to change the code to measure the time it takes to read it each time, and postpone the next reading to be `*100` of that (with minimum of 1 second). This way the worse effect would be a slowdown of 1%.
The only question that arises now, is if the progress repost (how many keys were saves) should always come with that, or do we sometimes send progress update without cow update?
Another thing to make sure of, is that we don't attempt to read the cow when the save is not done from a fork child (no child info pipe).

the measurement should probably include the time not just to get the file from /proc/self/smaps, but also the time spent parsing/etc. if this is causing the bgsave to go from ~300 to > 3000 seconds, and the smaps generation takes 1.3 seconds every 1 second, there's still a looooot of time not accounted for.

perhaps it would also make sense to make the *100 multiplier a default that is customizable via config settings? I honestly haven't ever wanted to check on progress and unless redis itself needs this data for something now I'd be likely to set it to 1000x or 10000x.

The parsing itself is very quick - just pushed this output to a test program and it's <1ms (probably way under). Perhaps Redis reads `/proc` even slower than `cat`, as it does not read it in a single chunk (I seem to remember it may make a difference in some cases).

If obtaining some timing output from this is useful to prevent guessing what matters and what doesn't I'd be happy to apply any code changes necessary and give it another go, left my test server up in case there was more info requested.

I don't think we wanna make it configurable. It's too low level. I think we can accept a 1% degradation. 
Obviously we'll measure the parsing time too, doing otherwise is complicated. 
The only question that remains is if the progress report should be at higher rate, or limited to the same intervals of  the cow report.

A couple of other thoughts about this:
* Recent kernels have `/proc/<pid>/smaps_rollup` which might be more efficient to use. Will need to test this though.
* We could have a background thread read and update the CoW metrics. It will be throttled as suggested but being in a thread will avoid slowing up the child.

@oranagra WDUT?

@yossigo cool about `smaps_rollup`, interesting to test if it's faster, but:
1. we'll still have to fallback to normal smaps, so either way we need a mechanism to throttle the COW reading.
2. even if smaps_rollup isn't faster to generate, maybe we wanna use it to speed parsing when available.

Regarding the thread idea, i thought of it too, but i'm not sure it worth the complication.
I think i'm willing to make compromise about the availability of the COW info in the parent rather than complicate that code.
i guess what would be best is that if the rollup will be faster, then the mechanism i described with the intervals will have good INFO intervals on newer kernels, and the slower one on older kernels.
@oranagra tested `smaps_rollup`, no real difference. It will save parsing time but that's negligible compared to the `stime` we spend anyway.
finally got around to testing this (using 6.2.3) and RDB bgsave times are performing well again, thanks again for the attention and fixes here.
